member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ContentCommandBase.Force
member.summary: Gets or sets the force property
member.remarks: Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.remarks: Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Conversion.TryParseHex(System.String,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Attempt to convert a string representation of a base-16 value into an integer.
member.param: A string containing the text to be parsed.
An integer into which the parsed value is stored. If the string cannot be converted, this parameter is set to 0.
member.returns: Returns true if the conversion was successful, false otherwise.
member.remarks: The hexString parameter must contain a hexadecimal value, with no base-indication prefix. For example, the string "0409" will be parsed into the base-10 integer value 1033, while the string "0x0409" will fail to parse due to the "0x" base-indication prefix.

member.param: A string containing WMI's notion (usually) of a locale.
member.returns: A CultureInfo object if successful, null otherwise.
member.remarks: This method first tries to convert the string to a hex value and get the CultureInfo object from that value. Failing that it attempts to retrieve the CultureInfo object using the locale string as passed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Processor.ProcessorID
member.summary: Processor information that describes the processor features.
member.remarks: For an x86 class CPU, the field format depends on the processor support of the CPUID instruction. If the instruction is supported, the property contains 2 (two) DWORD formatted values. The first is an offset of 08h-0Bh, which is the EAX value that a CPUID instruction returns with input EAX set to 1. The second is an offset of 0Ch-0Fh, which is the EDX value that the instruction returns. Only the first two bytes of the property are significant and contain the contents of the DX register at CPU resetall others are set to 0 (zero), and the contents are in DWORD format

member.summary: Number of logical processors available on the computer

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsNumberOfProcessors
member.summary: Number of physical processors currently available on a system.
member.remarks: This is the number of enabled processors for a system, which does not include the disabled processors. If a computer system has two physical processors each containing two logical processors, then the value of CsNumberOfProcessors is 2 and CsNumberOfLogicalProcessors is 4. The processors may be multicore or they may be hyperthreading processors

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsProcessors
member.summary: Array of objects describing each processor on the system.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsPartOfDomain
member.summary: If True, the computer is part of a domain. If the value is NULL, the computer is not in a domain or the status is unknown

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsPauseAfterReset
member.summary: Time delay before a reboot is initiated, in milliseconds. It is used after a system power cycle, local or remote system reset, and automatic system reset. A value of 1 (minus one) indicates that the pause value is unknown

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsPCSystemType

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ComputerInfo.CsPowerManagementSupported

member.remarks: This property does not indicate that power management features are enabled currently, but it does indicate that the logical device is capable of power management

member.remarks: A language identifier is a standard international numeric abbreviation for a country/region. Each language has a unique language identifier (LANGID), a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier

member.remarks: This value does not necessarily indicate the true amount of physical memory, but what is reported to the operating system as available to it.

member.summary: Total swap space in kilobytes
member.remarks: This value may be NULL (unspecified) if the swap space is not distinguished from page files. However, some operating systems distinguish these concepts. For example, in UNIX, whole processes can be swapped out when the free page list falls and remains below a specified amount

member.summary: DEP is enabled for all 32-bit applications on the computer

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.OptIn
member.summary: DEP is enabled for a limited number of binaries, the kernel, and all Windows-based services. However, it is off by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator must explicitly choose either the Always On or the Opt Out setting before DEP can be applied to 32-bit applications

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.DataExecutionPreventionSupportPolicy.OptOut
member.summary: DEP is enabled by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator can explicitly remove support for a 32-bit application by adding the application to an exceptions list

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Filter
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter property
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Filter parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Include
member.summary: Gets or sets the include property
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Include parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Exclude
member.summary: Gets or sets the exclude property
member.remarks: This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Exclude parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CoreCommandBase.Force
member.summary: Gets or sets the force property
member.remarks:
Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.
This is meant to be overridden by derived classes if they support the Force parameter. This property is on the base class to simplify the creation of the CmdletProviderContext.

member.remarks: Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.summary: Gets or sets the force property
member.remarks: Gives the provider guidance on how vigorous it should be about performing the operation. If true, the provider should do everything possible to perform the operation. If false, the provider should attempt the operation but allow even simple errors to terminate the operation. For example, if the user tries to copy a file to a path that already exists and the destination is read-only, if force is true, the provider should copy over the existing read-only file. If force is false, the provider should write an error.

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_InvalidClassName
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Cannot find the {0} class on the {1} CIM server. Verify the value of the ClassName xml attribute in Cmdlet Definition XML and retry. Valid class name example: ROOT\cimv2\Win32_Process. {StrContains="ClassName"} {StrContains="ROOT\cimv2\Win32_Process"} {0} is a placeholder for a name of a (potentially misspelled) CIM class. Example: "Win32_Process". {1} is a placeholder for a server name. Example: "localhost".

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.Xml_cmdletsOverObjectsXsd
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to ..\..\..\..\src\cimSupport\cmdletization\xml\cmdlets-over-objects.xsd;System.String, mscorlib, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089;utf-8{Locked}

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_MethodDescription
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to CIM method {1} on the {0} CIM object {0} is a placeholder for a CIM path. Example: \\SERVER1\ROOT\cimv2:Win32_Process.Handle="11828" {1} is a placeholder for a CIM method name. Example: Create

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_GenericCimFailure
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Failed to run {1}. {0} {0} is a placeholder for a generic CIM failure. Example: 'Invalid namespace' or '9' {1} is a placeholder for a description of CIM operation. This most likely comes from CimJob_MethodDescription or CimJob_QueryDescription

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_VerboseExecutionMessage
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Running the following operation: {0}. {0} is a placeholder for a description of CIM operation. This most likely comes from CimJob_MethodDescription or CimJob_QueryDescription

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.SessionBasedWrapper_ShouldProcessVsJobConflict
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to CIM cmdlets do not support the {0} parameter together with the AsJob parameter. Remove one of these parameters and retry. {StrContains="AsJob"} {0} is a placeholder for 'WhatIf' or 'Confirm' cmdlet parameters

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_SafeQueryDescription
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to CIM query for instances of the {0} class on the {1} CIM server: {2} {0} is a placeholder for a name of a CIM class. Example: "Win32_Process". {1} is a placeholder for a server name. Example: "localhost".

member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_ErrorCodeFromMethod

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The {2} CIM method exposed by the {0} class on the {1} CIM server {0} is a placeholder for a name of a CIM class. member.name: P:CmdletizationResources.CimJob_InvalidOutputParameterName
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Cannot find the {2} output parameter of the {1} method of the {0} CIM object. Verify the value of the ParameterName attribute in Cmdlet Definition XML and retry. {StrContains="ParameterName"} {0} is a placeholder for a CIM path. member.name: P:ProcessCommandHelpResources.GetProcessDetailedDescription
member.summary:
Looks up a localized string similar to
-Id id [int[]] [pipeline input allowed] Comma-separated list of process identifiers that specify the processes to get
-ProcessName name [string[]] [pipeline input allowed] Comma-separated list of process names that specify the processes to get
-Exclude name [ArrayList] Comma-separated list of process names to be excluded from the output.
--- The command enumerates processes from the local computer, and outputs System.Diagnostics.Process object(s). The command writes the process object to the output pipeline one at a time. The command takes parameters like ID(Process Identifier) or Process Name from the command line. The command returns the corresponding system.diagnostics.process for the supplied ID or ProcessName parameters.
